text:
Typhoon Koppu wreaks havoc as thousands flee their homes Published on : Sunday, October 18, 2015
As Typhoon Koppu started its lashing of the northern region of Philippines thousands of residents of the area were forced to flee Sunday.
The ravaging storm is forecast to blow over the country’s main island of Luzon at an excruciatingly slow pace and dump huge amounts of rain on the rugged terrain, setting off floods and landslides.
Koppu hit the shore in the early hours of Sunday at super typhoon strength, ripping the roofs off buildings and uprooting trees in the coastal province of Aurora.
Roads and communications to three towns in Aurora province have been severed by floods and landslides, including Casiguran, where the typhoon made landfall, authorities reported.
Around 15,000 people are taking shelter in evacuation centers, the Philippines’ disaster management agency said Sunday. No casualties have been reported so far, according to the agency.
The storm was packing maximum sustained winds of 240 kph (150 mph) when it slammed into the eastern coast of Luzon, according to the U.S. military’s Joint Typhoon Warning Center, although the Philippines’ national weather agency measured the winds as being significantly weaker, at 185 kph. The typhoon has since lost some of its strength as it has moved over land.
But much of the concern about Koppu’s impact centers on the extreme amounts of rain it’s expected to unleash.
“The big story out of this storm is definitely going to be the rainfall totals. Some areas are forecast to receive more than 1 meter (39 inches of rain) by the end of Wednesday.
The typhoon is predicted to dawdle across northern Luzon for several days because of a ridge of high pressure over China blocking its progress farther north. That gives it longer than usual to soak the region’s mountains and swell its rivers, threatening people who live downhill and downstream.
